wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement News Roundup 9/11/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

For California, El Ni o’s Dark Clouds Could Mean Rain but Also Trouble

California’s drought situation is one of the worst in the state’s recorded history, and a forecasted El Ni o has many people hopeful of an end to the water crisis. However, research shows that after an emergency, human behavior returns to what it was before the state of drought. The author brings to light the danger of reversing the positive behavior many California residents have made habit: this July, residents reduced their water use by 31%, as compared to July 2013. While this is a positive sign, state legislators, researchers and business leaders are continuing to encourage positive behavior change towards conversation.

Friends at Work? Not So Much

Americans are very social outside of work, yet when it comes to the office, our work culture tends to lean towards polite and impersonal. This article highlights research that shows job satisfaction increases when opportunities to form friendships are provided. Interestingly enough, groups of friends in the workplace outperform groups of acquaintances in both decision making and effort tasks. This supports a number of recent reports that show that work relationships (in addition to the quality of the manager) dramatically affect job satisfaction and commitment. Main takeaway: organizations need to find new and creative ways to engage their employees and enhance their company culture.

Unlocking the Secrets of Employee Engagement

Thought leader and founder of leading research firm, Bersin by Deloitte, Josh Bersin summarizes the latest data on employee engagement and offers advice to organizations based on what he and his team have observed. Now more than ever, employees are seeking more meaningful work; a positive work environment, continuous opportunities for growth and inspiring, capable, all-star management. Josh addresses issues such as traditional survey methods and feedback models, and offers a refreshed model for engagement based on 5 key frameworks. Ultimately, he urges executives to adapt to these changes in order move their organizations forward amidst a fast-paced workforce.

CSR: Fostering Responsible Biodiversity Stewardship

The author provides insight behind why biodiversity programs typically fail and why it’s important to business. The main reason includes: lack of program engagement with its people, communities and large economic entities. The author continues by proposing clear actions companies and managers can take to improve their efforts, but the only way to truly be successful is integrating these practices into work culture and engaging stakeholders.
